title: Untitled (Dream of Venus) formerly Visions of Eternity

thumbnail.alt_text: Painting of an arid landscape in blue, beige, and gray. At left, a dark figure-like form sits atop a beige archway, two gray kidney shapes below it.

description: This painting originally comprised the left-most portion of a much larger mural featured in the popular and salacious Dream of Venus pavilion, which Dalí created for the 1939 New York World’s Fair. Incorporating the artist’s major iconography of the decade, including a melting clock and a burning giraffe, the mural hung in the “dry” portion of the presentation. The adjacent “wet” aquarium featured a burlesque performance that complemented the pavilion’s celebration of classical beauty. The arched passage in this painting was mirrored on the mural’s right side in a panel that remains lost today.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Shapiro
publication_history:
Katherine Kuh and Dennis Adrian, The Mr. & Mrs. Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1985), 45, fig. 30, cat. 32 (color ill.), 109, cat. 32, as Visions of Eternity, 1936/37.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Annual Report 1987-88, pp. 9, 71, pl. 15, as Vision of Eternity.

Robert Descharnes and Gilles Néret, Salvador Dalí  1904-1989. Das Malerische Werk, vol 1 (Cologne: Benedikt Taschen, 1993), 286, cat. 640, as Sans titre, connu comme Vision de l’éternité.

Werner Spies, La Revolution Surrealiste, exh. cat. (Paris: Centre Pompidou, 2002), 260 (color ill.), 433.

Dawn Ades, Michael R. Taylor, and Montserrat Aguer, Dalí: The Centenary Retrospective, exh. cat. (New York : Rizzoli ; Philadelphia : In association with the Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2004), 279, cat. 171 (color ill.), as Untitled (Vision of Eternity, 1936-37).

Robert Rosenblum, Salvador Dalí: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Artforum, 43, no. 10 (Summer 2005), 320, (color ill.).

Stephanie D’Alessandro and Renée DeVoe Mertz, The Age of Picasso and Matisse: Modern Art at the Art Institute of Chicago, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2014), 128 (color ill.).

Kyle MacMillan, “Art Institute Exhibit Hoping to Rescue Salvador Dali’s Artistic Reputation,” Chicago Sun Times, Feb. 15, 2002, 20 (color ill.), 21.

Jacqui Palumbo, “Two art curators had a mystery on their hands. Was an unusual Dalí painting actually his?” CNN Style, Feb. 24, 2023 (color ill.), http://edition.cnn.com/style/article/salvador-dali-art-institute-of-chicago-dream-of-venus/index.html
exhibition_history:
The Art Institute of Chicago, The Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Randall Shapiro Collection, Feb. 23-Apr. 14, 1985, cat. 32, as Visions of Eternity, 1936/37.

Paris, Centre Georges Pompidou, La Revolution Surrealiste, Feb. 27– June 24, 2002, no cat. no.; Dusseldorf, Kunstsammlung Nordhein-Westfahlen, July 20–Nov. 24, 2002, as Vision de l'éternité, 1936–1937. 

Venice, Palazzo Grassi, Salvador Dalí, Sept. 12, 2004–Jan.16, 2005, cat. 171; Philadelphia Museum of Art, Feb. 6–May 15, 2005 (Philadelphia only), as Untitled (Vision of Eternity).

Fort Worth, Kimbell Art Museum, The Age of Picasso and Matisse: Modern Masters from the Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 6, 2013–Feb. 16, 2014, no cat. no., as Visions of Eternity.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Salvador Dalí: The Image Disappears, Feb. 18–June 12, 2023, no cat.
provenance_text: Commissioned by Dali World’s Fair (DWF) Company for the New York World’s Fair, Apr. 10, 1939 [DWF Co. contract, Apr. 10, 1939, Gala-Salvador Dalí Foundation, copy in curatorial object file]. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Shapiro, Chicago, by 1966 [Letter from Joseph Shapiro, Dec. 6, 1987, copy in curatorial object file]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1987.
copyright_notice:
© Salvador Dalí, Fundació Gala-Salvador Dalí / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York,
2018

input: Untitled (Dream of Venus) formerly Visions of Eternity
